snippet: Mitt Romney tried to use the White House’s handling of the attack on the American mission in Libya as a broad indictment of President Obama as commander in chief, while Mr. Obama accused Mr. Romney of politicizing a tragedy.
abstract: Mitt Romney, in second presidential debate, attempts to use Obama administration's shifting accounts of the attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, to indict Pres Obama's performance as commander in chief; Obama fires back, accusing Romney of politicizing a tragedy; moderator Cindy Crowley corrects Romney's assertion that the president had waited before characterizing the attacks as an act of terror.

byline.contributor: Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney tried to use the White House’s handling of the attack on the American mission in Libya as a broad indictment of President Obama as commander in chief, while Mr. Obama accused Mr. Romney of politicizing a tragedy.

headline.main: Attack on U.S. Mission in Benghazi Becomes Subject of Strongest Words
headline.print_headline: Attack on U.S. Mission in Benghazi Becomes Subject of Strongest Words

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
